perturbation.law_explanation: Texas Property Code § 53.157(c) states that the claimant must file suit to foreclose the lien within two years after the last date the claimant may file the lien affidavit, or within one year of completion of the work under the prime contract. Demanding the subcontractor to discharge a lien or furnish an indemnity bond within three days of notice contradicts the statutory timeframe for enforcement of a mechanic's lien.

perturbation.original_text: A copy of the (i) certificate(s) of insurance and (ii) endorsements, acceptable to EDGE, shall be submitted to EDGE prior to commencement of any Work and renewals or replacements of such certificates shall be so delivered at least 30 days prior to the expiration or termination of each such policy.
perturbation.changed_text: A copy of the (i) certificate(s) of insurance and (ii) endorsements, acceptable to EDGE, shall be submitted to EDGE prior to commencement of any Work and renewals or replacements of such certificates shall be so delivered at least 5 days prior to the expiration or termination of each such policy.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notification period for insurance renewals to 5 days may violate standard insurance regulations or contractual obligations in Texas that require more notice.
perturbation.law_explanation: Texas Insurance Code § 551.052 addresses notice requirements for policy cancellation and nonrenewal. While not directly mandating a specific 30-day notice for *submission* of renewal certificates, reducing the notice period to 5 days increases the risk that the subcontractor will fail to provide adequate notice of nonrenewal, potentially violating the insurance requirements set forth in the agreement and potentially violating the spirit of the Texas Insurance Code regulations regarding notice. Moreover, many insurance contracts themselves may require a 30 day notice, so compelling compliance 5 days before expiration is unrealistic and a violation of the party's duty to be able to comply with the requirements of the contract.

SUBCHAPTER B. CANCELLATION AND NONRENEWAL OF CERTAIN LIABILITY AND COMMERCIAL PROPERTY INSURANCE POLICIES Sec. 551.051. DEFINITIONS. In this subchapter: (1) "Commercial property insurance" has the meaning assigned by Section 2251.002 . (1-a) "Insurer" means an insurance company or other entity admitted to engage in business and authorized to write liability insurance or commercial property insurance in this state, including a county mutual insurance company, a Lloyd's plan, and a reciprocal or interinsurance exchange. The term does not include a county mutual fire insurance company that writes exclusively industrial fire insurance as described by Section 912.310 or a farm mutual insurance company. (2) "Liability insurance" means: (A) general liability insurance; (B) professional liability insurance other than medical professional liability insurance; (C) commercial automobile liability insurance; (D) commercial multiperil insurance; and (E) any other type or line of liability insurance designated by the department. Added by Acts 2003, 78th Leg., ch. 1274, Sec. 2, eff. April 1, 2005. Amended by: Acts 2019, 86th Leg., R.S., Ch. 72 (S.B. 590 ), Sec. 2, eff. September 1, 2019. Sec. 551.052. CANCELLATION PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS. (a) An insurer may not cancel a liability insurance or commercial property insurance policy that is a renewal or continuation policy. (b) An insurer may not cancel a liability insurance or commercial property insurance policy during the initial policy term after the 60th day following the date on which the policy was issued. (c) Notwithstanding Subsections (a) and (b), an insurer may cancel a liability insurance or commercial property insurance policy at any time during the term of the policy for: (1) fraud in obtaining coverage; (2) failure to pay premiums when due; (3) an increase in hazard within the control of the insured that would produce a rate increase; or (4) loss of the insurer's reinsurance covering all or part of the risk covered by the policy. (d) Notwithstanding Subsections (a) and (b), an insurer may cancel a liability insurance or commercial property insurance policy at any time during the term of the policy if the insurer is placed in supervision, conservatorship, or receivership and the cancellation or nonrenewal is approved or directed by the supervisor, conservator, or receiver. Added by Acts 2003, 78th Leg., ch. 1274, Sec. 2, eff. April 1, 2005. Amended by: Acts 2019, 86th Leg., R.S., Ch. 72 (S.B. 590 ), Sec. 3, eff. September 1, 2019. Sec. 551.053. WRITTEN NOTICE OF CANCELLATION REQUIRED. Not later than the 10th day before the date on which the cancellation of a liability insurance or commercial property insurance policy takes effect, an insurer must deliver or mail written notice of the cancellation to the first-named insured under the policy at the address shown on the policy. perturbation.justification: The changed text reduces the notification period for insurance renewals from 30 days to 5 days. The Law Explanation suggests this could violate the 'spirit' of Texas Insurance Code regulations regarding notice, even if it doesn't directly mandate a 30-day notice for submitting renewal certificates. Scraped Law Snippet 1 and 2, specifically Texas Insurance Code § 551.052, addresses notice requirements for policy cancellation and nonrenewal but doesn't explicitly state a 30-day requirement for submitting renewal certificates. However, § 551.053 requires an insurer to deliver or mail written notice of cancellation not later than the 10th day before the cancellation takes effect. While this relates to cancellation by the insurer, it indicates the importance of providing adequate notice related to insurance matters. The Perturbation Explanation suggests potential violations of insurance regulations requiring more notice, which supports a possible contradiction, although not a direct violation of the provided statutes. The contradiction score is 0.6 because while no specific law mandates a 30-day notice for certificate submission, the reduced timeframe increases the risk of non-compliance with general notice requirements related to insurance policies as suggested by the 'spirit' of the law.

perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period to 5 days could be deemed unreasonable and contradict general contract law principles requiring reasonable opportunity to cure defaults.
perturbation.law_explanation: While not directly applicable, Texas Business and Commerce Code Chapter 24 (Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act) illustrates the importance of fair consideration and reasonable opportunity in business transactions. While not a direct contradiction, reducing the cure period to 5 days may be deemed commercially unreasonable in many construction scenarios, potentially leading to a court finding the termination clause unconscionable, or that the short cure period constitutes a breach of the implied duty of good faith and fair dealing, because it deprives the subcontractor of an actual opportunity to cure. A five day period to 'cure' may also violate mechanic's lien laws if the reason for default has to do with subcontractors filing liens, in that a longer statutory period is provided for such lien actions than the time given to cure.

(b) For the purposes of Sections 24.005 (a)(2) and 24.006 of this code, a person gives a reasonably equivalent value if the person acquires an interest of the debtor in an asset pursuant to a regularly conducted, noncollusive foreclosure sale or execution of a power of sale for the acquisition or disposition of the interest of the debtor upon default under a mortgage, deed of trust, or security agreement. (c) A transfer is made for present value if the exchange between the debtor and the transferee is intended by them to be contemporaneous and is in fact substantially contemporaneous. (d) "Reasonably equivalent value" includes without limitation, a transfer or obligation that is within the range of values for which the transferor would have sold the assets in an arm's length transaction.
